title: Plan to stop people voting without photo ID confirmed in Queen’s Speech
text:
Queen Elizabeth II and the Prince of Wales during the State Opening of Parliament (Picture: PA)

A controversial plan to prevent people from voting unless they carry photographic ID at polling stations has been confirmed in the Queen’s Speech today.

The government had been accused of attempting to suppress voters’ rights after the idea to introduce compulsory photo ID for voters was leaked.

Its proposals involve making it compulsory to show ID such as driving licences or passports at the ballot box to be able to vote in a general or local election.

Campaigners argue the move is a threat to democratic participation.

During the speech, the Queen spoke of the importance of ‘protecting the integrity of democracy and the electoral system’.

The move is intended to ‘tackle electoral fraud and protect our democracy’, and is among a number of electoral changes the government is seeking to introduce.

Under the scheme, anyone who does not have photographic ID will be able to apply for a free document proving their identity, the government says.

A trial of the scheme in local elections this year reportedly saw almost 800 people turned away from polling stations.

The Electoral Reform Society (ERS) said the plan risks ‘raising the drawbridge to huge numbers of marginalised voters’, including the elderly and BAME voters.

It said that out of millions of votes cast in the UK last year, there were just eight allegations of personation fraud – the type of fraud that voter ID is meant to prevent.

ERS chief executive Darren Hughes said: ‘The government have sat on their hands in the face of the actual threats to electoral integrity: anonymous ‘dark ads’, dodgy donations and disinformation. Instead of taking on the real issues, they are using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.

‘Make no mistake, these plans will leave tens of thousands of legitimate voters voiceless. Ministers should focus on combating the real threats to our democracy, rather than suppressing voters’ rights.’

He added: ‘This gamble with our democracy will strike many voters as US-style gerrymandering, with Britain’s tradition of trust at the ballot box abolished in one swoop. Ministers must think again.’

The ERS told the Guardian it estimates photo ID for voting would cost up to £20 million to enforce per election.
